1.brief: properly, to eye or (generally) to heed, i.e. pay attention; by implication, to respond; by extension to begin to speak; specifically to sing, shout, testify, announce
Ijob, the patriarch famous for his patience

2.brief: a conditional particle; if; by implication (interj. as a wish) would that!
to suspend or poise (especially in trade)
to suspend or poise (especially in trade)
(only in the dual) a pair of scales
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative

at this time, whether adverb, conjunction or expletive

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south

above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
to gulp; figuratively, to be rash

properly, a piercer, i.e. an arrow; by implication, a wound; figuratively, (of God) thunderbolt; the shaft of aspear
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
heat; figuratively, anger, poison (from its fever)

to set in a row, i.e. arrange, put in order (in a very wide variety of applications)

5.brief: to bray (as an ass), scream (from hunger)

properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)

to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a petition; by implication, a loan
literally a cord (as an attachment); figuratively, expectancy

to loosen, i.e. relinquish, permit, etc.
